in order to stimulate creativeness in the application of closed-circuit television to
its maximal usefulness in the educational program, teachers will be given an oppor¬
tunity during the first year to explore and develop their ideas about its use. It is
not possible at present, nor does it seem desirable to attempt to outline the full
scope of the things that may be done because the teachers themselves will be par¬
ticipating continuously in the planning and in the making of decisions.
While much of the first year must be devoted to an orientation of teachers to the
new medium and to the designing of ways of providing effective instruction, it is
intended that the scope of what is attempted be broad and comprehensive from the
very start of the project. It is, therefore, proposed that ways of implementing the
program include simultaneous developments in the following areas: (1) Direct in¬
struction, (2) Supplemental instruction, (3) In-service teacher training, and (4)
Public relations.
